image.altText: An image of the Dunstan by-election candidates.

props.synopsis: More than 24 hours after polling booths closed in the Dunstan by-election, voters are yet to officially find out who will succeed the state's former premier, Steven Marshall, in the state's most marginal seat.

title.children: Why don't voters officially know who the next Dunstan MP is?

image.altText: A space with computers and desks is pictured with students working.

props.synopsis: Education Minister Jason Clare will today announce $16 million to fund 10 new study hubs in Victoria, Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania to better support students who live far from campus.

title.children: Five states to get new study hubs to lift university enrolment in regions

image.altText: The torso and arms of a boy infected with measles showing a rash on his skin.

props.synopsis: Health authorities says a case of measles has been detected in an infant who was at a range of public venues in Adelaide over the past week.

title.children: SA Health issues alert after baby contracts measles

image.altText: Students and man in orange and blue space suits collect rocks in rocky terrain simulated crater beside rover

props.synopsis: An Australian-built lunar rover has been designed to help extract resources like oxygen and metals to enable astronauts to breathe in space and create rocket fuel during NASA's next mission to the moon.

title.children: Moon mining rover set to utilise 'infinite resources and energy of space', extracting oxygen and metals from lunar soil

image.altText: Kitchen worker uses tongs in a pub kitchen in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The government will advocate that the wages of Australia's lowest-paid workers do not go backwards, as the Fair Work Commission reviews minimum and award wage rates.

title.children: Government pushes for minimum wage increase to keep pace with inflation, so worker pay does not go backwards

image.altText: A composite image of two men, whose faces are slightly in shadow. They are each looking to the side with serious expressions.

props.synopsis: Military lawyer David McBride gave journalist Dan Oakes more than a hundred classified military documents. Both are still living with the consequences.

title.children: Their lives collided over a bundle of classified military files. Neither would be the same again

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaks to the press club in a stern, close-up shot

props.synopsis: A fierce battle over housing is set to define the next federal election as Labor, the Coalition and the Greens target a growing cohort of voters who believe they've been locked out of home ownership for life, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: 'Who do we fight for?': The question the major parties must grapple with if they want to sway young voters

image.altText: A woman wearing a headscarf waters plants in a small courtyard. She is smiling.

props.synopsis: Lack of data about the impact of cancer treatments on fertility and ovarian function is an "enormous oversight" and a "disservice to women," experts say.

title.children: Pamela wants to know if immunotherapy will affect her fertility — but doctors don't have an answer

image.altText: Dark silhouette of a person wearing a hoodie.

props.synopsis: Inflation isn't just hitting households, it's also affecting scammers with the price of stolen documents like passports and driver's licences skyrocketing on the dark web. But the price to hack someone's email has fallen by 60 per cent, and experts warn consumers and businesses need to stay vigilant.

title.children: It's criminal — cost of fake passports and IDs soaring on the dark web

image.altText: three men wearing kufis standing in a line with their hands in front of them

props.synopsis: In regional South Australia, minority religions such as Sikhism are growing, while some Christian churches are looking for ways to adapt as congregations shrink.

title.children: Increasing migration reflected in Australia's shifting religious identity

image.altText: Russell Crowe stars in a scene from the movie Robin Hood

props.synopsis: As a heated by-election campaign wrapped up for former South Australian Premier Steven Marshall's former seat, the SA Liberals converged on their scene of defeat at the last state election.

title.children: Robin Hood and the duel for SA's most marginal seat

image.altText: A woman looks out of a hotel window

props.synopsis: Four years after Australia's hotel quarantine system was enacted to slow the spread of COVID-19, states and territories are still struggling to recoup the money they spent establishing and managing the scheme.

title.children: Find out how much your state is still owed from unpaid hotel quarantine bills

image.altText: A building site with no workers in site.

props.synopsis: The construction industry warns the federal government's goal of building 1.2 million new well-located homes in the next five years will begin on the back foot because of a significant worker shortage.

title.children: 90,000 extra construction workers needed for goal of 1.2 million new homes, industry says

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff walks through a crowded room and cameras film him.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Liberals might have spent the weekend looking at the result of the election for a newly expanded parliament and wondering what exactly was the point, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: Rockliff thought expanding Tasmania's parliament would make life easier. The electorate had other ideas

image.altText: A man looks at a woman with dark hair

props.synopsis: After his office initially failed to execute a viable PR plan to protect his family, Prince William may now have time and space to focus on his wife's health and the wellbeing of his children. But the heir to the British throne has a rocky road ahead.

title.children: Queen Elizabeth once spoke of 1992 as her 'annus horribilis'. For William, his might be 2024

image.altText: China

props.synopsis: As China considers changes to the rights of workers there are concerns about the impact on businesses and how the solutions would be implemented.

title.children: China is considering making bosses pay workers for 'invisible' overtime, but is it a feasible solution?

image.altText: A slightly smiling middle-aged woman leans against a wooden post, in front of a beach. Dark curly hair, glasses, blue top.

props.synopsis: A growing proportion of older couples in relationships that span over decades are splitting up, with about one in four divorces taking place after the age of 50. But experts warn it could have significant implications for the wider society.

title.children: Leanne separated from her spouse of 20 years when she was 53. She's not alone

image.altText: A woman crouches down to the ground to light a candle surrounded by other candles, flowers and plush toys.

props.synopsis: Russia marks a day of mourning with people leaving flowers outside the concert hall where at least 137 people were killed in an attack on Friday.

title.children: Russia mourns victims of concert hall attack as death toll rises to 137

image.altText: Thousands of people in shawls sit on the ground near a monument under blue sky

props.synopsis: Thousands of people in Ladakh demand action from the Indian government to protect the region's ecology and greater autonomy over how their land is used.

title.children: 'Climate fast' protest enters third week as thousands demand action in freezing temperatures in India

image.altText: Marilyn adjusts Audra's wedding veil

props.synopsis: Marilyn Rulyancich's baby was snatched from her during Australia's forced adoption era. But she never gave up hope of seeing her again — and now she's telling her remarkable story of subterfuge, detective work and sheer determination.

title.children: When Audra got married, she had no idea her mother she never met was standing right behind her

image.altText: A pink building.

props.synopsis: India has denied killing Hardeep Singh Nijjar, but an ABC investigation has found evidence government agencies were searching his family home in Punjab in the weeks before his death.

title.children: What happened at this pink building in remote India could hold new clues in a killing that rocked the world

image.altText: The rooftops of houses.

props.synopsis: Prosper Australia says if we were smarter about taxing land, we could slash taxes on workers and businesses, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: If we taxed land properly, we'd have billions of extra dollars to fund big tax cuts elsewhere. So why don't we do it?

image.altText: Man pours beer at pub bar

props.synopsis: Cousins Joe Bishop and Luke Symonds were in central-west New South Wales for a construction job when they heard a pub was for sale. Despite no experience pouring beers, running a kitchen or owning a hotel, they decided to make an offer.

title.children: When Neville's pub closed, the town went 'dead'. Then two cousins bought the hotel on a whim

image.altText: Bill Shorten standing in front of a NDIS logo

props.synopsis: NDIS participants exploited by unfair price hikes can now report price gouging to a new taskforce.

title.children: Government launches NDIS taskforce to crack down on providers overcharging participants

image.altText: bushfire at night

props.synopsis: Residents in Western Australia's south-west face a second nervous night as an out-of-control bushfire continues to burn. Properties have been impacted by the fire in bushland between Pinjarra and Waroona with crews battling difficult terrain and gusty winds.

title.children: Residents brace for another nervous night as WA bushfire continues to spread

image.altText: Composite of Lando Norris, Carlos Sainz, Charles Leclerc

props.synopsis: McLaren disappoints Australian fans in Melbourne, Carlos Sainz improves his resume for future job interviews, while Max Verstappen drove with a "handbrake".

title.children: Five quick hits — Oscar asked to move over for Norris, Carlos improves CV for future jobs, Verstappen drives with a 'handbrake'

image.altText: A GWS AFL player is shown with legs extended after a big kick for goal.

props.synopsis: GWS wraps up round two with a solid win over West Coast in Perth, with Essendon's Peter Wright set to face the tribunal on Tuesday night for the hit that left Sydney's Harry Cunningham concussed.

title.children: Giants' big win over Eagles wraps up round two, as Bombers' Wright sent straight to tribunal

image.altText: woman in a cream sweater lies on a couch with white headphones on

props.synopsis: Climate activist Greta Thunberg describes herself as having Asperger's while others on the autism spectrum, such as comedian Hannah Gatsby, describe themselves as "autistic". But what's the difference?

title.children: What’s the difference between autism and Asperger’s disorder?

image.altText: People wearing bright coloured clothing stand together at a Nigerian school.

props.synopsis: Authorities say students abducted by gunmen from a school in northern Nigeria have been released unharmed.

title.children: Nigerian children released after being abducted from school

image.altText: Julia Baird, who has short brown-blonde hair and is wearing a black wetsuit, looks over the ocean in morning sunlight

props.synopsis: One of the greatest myths is that by just being positive, or cheerful, we can somehow erase our problems. What I'm more interested in is the simpler question of: how do we go on?

title.children: 'Seven times down, eight times up': When life is hard, how do we go on?

image.altText: Large radio telescopes in the outback with a star filled sky.

props.synopsis: Humans have long been fascinated by how aliens could communicate — it's the plot of countless blockbuster science fiction films. Yet there's also a team of experts who are investigating this idea.

title.children: Meet the team preparing for the possibility that intelligent life exists beyond our galaxy

image.altText: Danielle Woodward wears glasses and a blue jacket and white top.

props.synopsis: ACT Magistrate Court documents reveal Commander Danielle Woodward was stood down from the Australian Federal Police after registering a blood-alcohol reading nearly three times the legal limit in November.

title.children: AFP Commander and Olympian Danielle Woodward charged with drink driving after crashing car into tree

image.altText: A police man standing in high-vis next to a police wagon, parked across a road

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police took a 32-year-old man, who they believe to be the driver of the vehicle, into custody and seized a Ford Ranger on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: Alleged fatal hit-and-run in Alice Springs being treated as possible death in custody

image.altText: A woman wearing a hat rests her arm on top of a rusted refrigerator while a small dog waits next to her.

props.synopsis: He didn't know it at the time, but Wes Herring wasn't standing alone on the precipice of breaking point — we explore how he and others are overcoming the mental torments of life on the land.

title.children: How the rigours of rural life are taking a heavy toll in the bush
